required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Brain and Muscle Plasticity During Immobilization
clinical_study.official_title: Examining Changes in Muscle Size and Strength, Neuromuscular Function, and Brain Plasticity During Limb Immobilization in Women

brief_summary.textblock:
Patients in rehabilitation may undergo periods of prolonged limb immobilization in response to injury, surgery, or illness. Due to disuse, the size and strength of muscles controlling the affected limb can decrease significantly, possibly resulting in physical impairment or lower quality of life during the recovery phase. Prior immobilization studies have shown that the rate and degree of decline in muscle strength exceeds that of muscle size, indicating that determinants of muscle strength unrelated to muscle size may further contribute to functional changes during immobilization.
The purpose of this study is to describe the changes in muscle strength, muscle size, corticospinal excitability, voluntary activation, M1 cortical thickness, and resting state functional connectivity following a 2-week limb immobilization period in young women.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in isometric elbow flexion and extension peak torque, both arms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
primary_outcome.description: Measured using an isokinetic dynamometer; peak torque during static contraction of the elbow flexors and extensors

primary_outcome.measure: Change in isokinetic elbow flexion and extension peak torque, both arms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
primary_outcome.description: Measured using an isokinetic dynamometer; peak torque during dynamic contraction of the elbow flexors and extensors

primary_outcome.measure: Change in cross-sectional area of the elbow flexor and extensor muscles, both arms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
primary_outcome.description: Obtained from magnetic resonance images of each arm

primary_outcome.measure: Change in volume of the elbow flexor and extensor muscles, both arms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
primary_outcome.description: Obtained from magnetic resonance images of each arm

primary_outcome.measure: Voluntary activation of biceps brachii, both arms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
primary_outcome.description: Measured using peripheral nerve stimulation and an isokinetic dynamometer; estimation of the capacity to voluntarily activate the force-generating elements of the biceps brachii during maximal effort elbow flexion

primary_outcome.measure: Change in corticospinal excitability of biceps brachii, both arms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before immobilization and 24 hours of left arm immobilization, and before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
primary_outcome.description: Measured using transcranial magnetic stimulation; estimation of the efficacy of the corticospinal tract to relay electrical signals to the biceps brachii muscle

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in right and left primary motor cortex thickness
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
secondary_outcome.description: Obtained from magnetic resonance image of the brain

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in whole brain resting state functional connectivity
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison between before and after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization
secondary_outcome.description: Obtained from magnetic resonance image of the brain

other_outcome.measure: 2-day caloric and macronutrient intake, before immobilization
other_outcome.time_frame: Measured during the 2-day period right before left arm immobilization
other_outcome.description: Obtained using self-reported dietary intake records

other_outcome.measure: 2-day caloric and macronutrient intake, during immobilization
other_outcome.time_frame: Measured during the last 2 days of left arm immobilization
other_outcome.description: Obtained using self-reported dietary intake records

other_outcome.time_frame: Measured on day of left arm immobilization, before putting on the arm brace
Measured after 2 weeks of left arm immobilization

intervention.description: Immobilization of left arm using a brace and sling.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Biologically female
- Right-hand dominant
- Body mass index between 18.5-30 kg/m^2 (inclusive)
- Regular menstrual cycle
- Be able to maintain a habitual diet throughout the duration of the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Use of tobacco
- Pregnancy
- A history of brain trauma
- Suffers from a neurological disease or movement disorder
- Peripheral nerve damage
- Use of medications known to affect protein metabolism (i.e., corticosteroids, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or prescription strength acne medications)
- Diagnosed with or suspects having a psychiatric illness
- Use of dietary supplements known to affect muscle size (i.e., creatine, fish oil)
- Past or present diagnosis of an eating disorder by a physician or registered dietician
- Possesses any metal implants (e.g. artificial joints, pacemakers, stents) or non-removeable medical devices that are contraindicative for magnetic resonance imaging (e.g. insulin pumps)

facility.name: Exercise Metabolism and Nutrition Research Laboratory
